briefing.opening: Good morning. We will now begin the climate briefing for January 2, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Strengthening Domestic Climate Crisis Adaptation and Carbon Neutrality Policies
sections.content: Domestically today, news of strengthened local community climate crisis adaptation efforts and carbon neutrality policies stood out. Gangbuk-gu, Seoul, is establishing its '3rd Climate Crisis Adaptation Plan,' to be implemented from 2026 to 2030, enhancing responses to heatwaves and torrential rains and building a foundation for disaster preparedness [1, 2, 3, 5, 6, 7, 9, 10]. Furthermore, Seongbuk-gu has designated a basic environmental education center, laying the groundwork to become a leading carbon-neutral city and an environmental education city [17, 19, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24]. Sunchon National University is also operating a climate literacy academy for youth, linking climate change with Suncheon Bay, thereby raising climate awareness among future generations [4]. Meanwhile, a move to redefine the direction of national climate response was observed as the '2050 Carbon Neutrality and Green Growth Committee' changed its name to the 'National Climate Crisis Response Committee' [8]. In addition, the carbon neutrality points accumulation system has been reinstated, and green procurement standards are being strengthened, indicating a sustained commitment to carbon neutrality policies [15, 16].

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Renewable Energy Expansion Efforts and Achievements
sections.content: In the renewable energy sector, various organizations are actively pursuing expansion efforts. The Ministry of Climate is promoting a complete redesign of the renewable energy supply system, shifting from RPS (Renewable Portfolio Standard) to a bidding mechanism, seeking a more efficient energy transition [25]. The Korea Energy Agency has opened new possibilities by launching a pilot project for utilizing 'off-site renewable energy' to secure energy self-sufficiency in Zero Energy Buildings (ZEB) [26, 31, 37, 40, 41, 42, 46, 53, 59, 63]. Notably, Chungcheongnam-do Province and Samsung Display are actively pursuing an RE100 implementation pilot project to install solar power facilities on public idle land, setting an exemplary case [29, 50, 51, 52, 58, 60, 61, 62, 66, 70, 72, 73, 74, 75]. Gunsan City has declared 2026 as the 'First Year of Korea's Renewable Energy Capital,' presenting a vision to integrate renewable energy achievements into citizens' daily lives [34, 38, 48, 54, 57, 64, 65]. Furthermore, various other institutions, including Korea National Railway, Incheon City Gas, and Korea Midland Power, have expressed their commitment to leading new and renewable energy projects and generating results, accelerating the nationwide renewable energy transition [13, 35, 36, 39, 67].

sections.title: âš ï¸ Challenges and Hurdles in Renewable Energy Transition
sections.content: Amidst positive movements in renewable energy transition, challenges and hurdles that need to be addressed are emerging. The Lee Jae-myung administration is expected to face a mountain of climate tasks in 2026, including amendments to the Carbon Neutrality Act and the establishment of plastic countermeasures. It is pointed out that carbon neutrality policies must now be demonstrated with concrete results [11, 14]. Particularly, in relation to achieving 100GW of renewable energy, a 'triple burden' issue is arising, and while electricity market restructuring is accelerating [30], in Jeollanam-do, a leading region for renewable energy, the problem of increasing power plants but inadequate transmission of generated electricity is intensifying [32]. This raises a fundamental question about whether South Korea is truly prepared as renewable energy emerges as the center of the global electricity market [43]. Even New Zealand, where renewable energy accounts for 85% of electricity generation, has not been able to completely abandon fossil fuels, demonstrating that the renewable energy transition is not simple [69].

sections.title: ğŸŒ Global Climate Response: Realities and Warnings
sections.content: Internationally, key conference schedules for climate change response have been confirmed, and simultaneously, clear signals of climate breakdown have been observed. The UN Climate Change Conference COP31 is scheduled to be held in Antalya, TÃ¼rkiye, in November 2026, which will be a crucial opportunity for the world to reconvene to achieve climate goals [76]. However, separate from these international efforts, over the past nine years, hundreds of native plant species have been observed flowering in winter in the UK, which is interpreted as a visible sign of climate breakdown [77]. The phenomenon where an average of 2.5 additional plant species flower during the New Year period for every 1Â°C rise in temperature in specific regions demonstrates the direct ecological impacts of climate change [77]. Furthermore, multilateralism is under pressure due to geopolitical factors and populism, raising concerns that the future of climate cooperation post-COP30 may be vulnerable [78].

briefing.closing: Today's briefing highlighted ongoing climate crisis response efforts both domestically and internationally, the complex challenges of renewable energy transition, and the clear signs of climate change already unfolding before our eyes. Sustained attention and concrete action are more crucial now than ever. This concludes today's climate briefing.

summary.phenomenon: An analysis of annual New Year's plant hunt data over the past nine years in the UK reveals that hundreds of native plant species, including daisies and dandelions, are blooming during winter.
